6.16.text:
Digital inequality has been
an area of interest to me

8.64.text:
probably because of the environment
that I grew up in.

11.84.text:
My dad worked, as what I can only describe
as a self-employed professional hacker.

16.21.text:
He used to be able
to be employed by clients

18.77.text:
to fix, rebuild, or repurpose,
whatever a client asked for.

24.07.text:
From that, we found that we grew up
in a "Wallace and Gromit" style house;

27.95.text:
nothing in our house
was ever really "broken",

32.93.text:
you can imagine a light-switch
being part of a recycled toaster.

39.68.text:
often found ourselves ahead of the curve
when it came to digital skills in school.

44.04.text:
But in my area of youth work,
I've come across a lot of young people

47.89.text:
that have been really affected
by digital inequality,

51.03.text:
and seen the adverse
effects of digital implication.

55.86.text:
Digital inequality is how we refer
to the social and economic inequality

60.54.text:
in regards to access to, use of,
or impact of, digital technologies.

66.47.text:
One way we can look at this issue
is to imagine a road with many toll gates.

70.10.text:
At the end of that road
is being digitally literate.

73.44.text:
A tollgate is a barrier that stops
people from moving forward,

76.39.text:
and things like access to technology,
or the ability to use technology

80.51.text: stops people early on in this toll gate.

82.54.text: Those people who have been stuck early on

85.07.text:
are now falling further and further
behind those who are at the front.

89.06.text: Every time the power of the web increases,

91.05.text:
and it's possible
to do more things online,

93.21.text:
the gap between those
who are digitally literate,

99.66.text:
can, of course, combine
with existing inequalities

103.53.text:
and do something worse by creating
them onto a digital setting as well.

108.43.text:
renowned for being at the forefront
of technological development,

111.48.text:
in the city where the founder of the web,
Tim Berners-Lee, was born,

116.10.text:
what possible digital
inequality could we have?

119.03.text:
Well, it's reckoned
that about 19.2 million households

123.20.text: are now hooked up to the web.

124.60.text:
This is a good thing,
that's always rising.

126.63.text:
But only 26% of those
on the lowest incomes.

131.46.text:
they reckon that about 16 million people
in this country lack basic online skills.

138.16.text:
I saw this brilliant Google ad
the other day, and it says,

145.09.text: and it's got the "not" crossed out.

146.93.text:
That might be true
if you've always got the Google app.

149.63.text:
But to have the Google app,
you have to have access to the Internet.

153.63.text:
You have to have a smartphone
to be able to use it.

156.42.text:
And also the education
about how a smartphone works.

159.57.text:
So, knowledge is always within reach,
if you have access to all those things.

165.71.text:
but that doesn't mean everyone 
has the opportunity to use it.

170.44.text: I was at a talk where Lord Chris Holmes

172.53.text:
said something that struck
a chord with me, which is,

175.01.text:
"How do we psychologically
prepare a generation

177.21.text:
to take their place
in the digital economy?"

179.47.text: And that really got me thinking.

181.14.text:
The principle of changing our beliefs
based on what's happening in the world

185.96.text:
the world goes through
this change all the time.

188.24.text:
Technology has always driven a shift 
in change of beliefs and perceptions.

193.14.text:
So, let's rewind to the pre-industrialised
era, where about 80% of jobs

198.57.text:
were all industrialised-based,
and they were agricultural.

202.79.text:
And involved a lot of hard work
to be able to move forward.

205.99.text:
In these progressions,
they were very labour-intensive

208.61.text:
and it would take many years to become
established at what you were doing.

212.10.text:
But once you did,
you would have a career for life.

214.48.text:
The process of product development 
was long and arduous

217.40.text:
and these things took
lots of time to be able to create.

221.85.text:
This brought about the growth
of industrialisation.

224.75.text: There are many dark sides to this growth,

227.09.text:
like long working hours, and poor
social conditions when working.

230.15.text: Not good things, we don't like those.

232.55.text:
But, there were a lot
of social gains as well.

236.65.text:
The price of products decreased, resulting
in an enhanced quality of living.

240.37.text:
It produced new jobs, and, for a short
while, a rise in the employment rate.

244.83.text:
But, in my opinion, the con
of the industrialised revolution

247.74.text:
is happening again
in the digital revolution.

250.87.text:
As technology takes the place
of humans in the workplace,

255.05.text: it results in an unemployment rate

257.09.text:
rising for those who lack
competencies and skills.

260.66.text:
I'm not a luddite
by any stretch of the imagination

263.04.text: - you'll probably find that out later on -

265.36.text:
I don't think the development
of technology is a bad thing, per se.

268.86.text:
But it does change
the shape of the economy,

273.34.text:
Disruption isn't the goal;
change is the goal.

275.97.text:
Disruption is often
just a by-product of change.

280.02.text:
We need to start to think about the human
implications of this change.

285.41.text:
one only needs to go to a supermarket
and look at the self-service checkout,

289.08.text:
or the automatisation
of blue-collar worker jobs

293.47.text:
Or, in the not too distant
future, self-driving cars.

296.41.text:
For someone who can't drive,
I'm really looking forward to that one.

300.27.text:
These are just a few ways we can see
technology eroding the human element

306.43.text:
And these skills and trades
are all in the process

308.76.text:
of having production slowly
moved away from people

311.10.text:
and slowly beginning to change the shape
of the job market as they do it.

314.53.text:
If we can visualise the job market
in the industrialised era,

317.54.text:
it would look something like this chest
of drawers kind of shape.

321.93.text:
You'd have low-paid, you'd have high-paid,
and you'd have your middle-paid.

325.49.text:
The middle section would contain jobs
like book-keeping, clerical work,

328.87.text:
and these would provide
typically middle-class pay.

332.01.text:
But, this is the section
in the information age

338.33.text:
And it creates a shape
that looks more like an eye-shape,

342.82.text:
where the middle-class paying
jobs are beginning to

346.97.text:
which are things like restaurant
workers, health home aides.

349.88.text:
Customer-service facing roles,
which are quite difficult to automate.

354.50.text:
It's expected that actually around 35%
of jobs that we currently know

360.04.text:
are going to be automated
within the next 20 years.

363.52.text:
Economic theory and government
policy will have to be rethought

366.64.text:
if technology is, indeed, destroying jobs
faster than it is creating new ones.

371.49.text:
This is where we need to evaluate
what kind of future we are are building.

374.97.text:
as the digital economy
might look very different

377.22.text: to any model that we currently know.

379.40.text:
If that is the case, it's dangerous
to the development of a generation

384.73.text:
"A high standard of living is purely
the result of intelligence and hard work",

389.53.text:
when that's not necessarily true,
and, debatable if it ever was.

394.78.text:
I would like to stress
the value of digital skills,

397.25.text: and their importance in the job market.

400.12.text:
According to a study by Telefonica
at the end of 2013,

403.70.text: it's estimated that we are going to need

405.85.text:
three quarters million digitally
skilled workers by 2017.

410.86.text:
For not being able to make that, 
it will cost the UK economy

415.51.text: Also, 27% of all job growth in London

420.53.text:
is generated by the digital
and tech sector.

424.52.text:
I believe as we prepare young people
for the digital economy,

427.39.text:
we need to have a far more
humanistic approach.

432.08.text:
my dad would spend a lot of time
teaching me how to problem-solve.

436.63.text:
Basically, to be able
to find answers for myself.

438.94.text:
My mother, on the other hand,
was very spiritual.

441.40.text:
She used to say a lot of things about 
the fair treatment of people.

445.36.text:
When I was fifteen, I already had the rug
pulled out from under my feet.

449.64.text: I began to have tonic-clonic seizures,

451.49.text:
sometimes up to several times
a day, multiple times a week.

454.92.text: Had a huge impact on my education.

456.94.text:
I developed a real pick-and-mix
of mental health issues

459.84.text:
problems such as anxiety, depressive
states, post-traumatic stress,

467.15.text:
and I felt like my identity was robbed
from me, because I couldn't identify

471.05.text:
how I was going to take
my place in the world.

474.05.text:
I started to display 
challenging behaviour at school.

476.60.text:
I was really struggling
to retain information in class.

479.31.text:
So, I used some of my technical
savvy to try and compensate.

482.14.text:
But often, my efforts were
a little bit misguided.

484.50.text:
I'd do things like break
into the teacher's laptop

487.11.text: to download the answers to tests,

489.50.text:
I'd create short executable
files on memory stick

492.24.text:
and disguise them as my homework,
and then I'd stick them into the computer

495.90.text:
and try to convince my teacher
that they accidentally deleted my homework

501.18.text:
When all else failed, "Emergency Plan A",
was, I hack the school network,

505.22.text:
and gave remote access
to the whole sixth form

507.36.text:
so they could control
all the computers around school.

509.90.text:
That meant they were opening
inappropriate web links

512.36.text:
on everyone's computers,
while they were trying to do the lesson.

518.94.text:
I put a lot of effort
into my self-preservation at the time.

523.69.text:
Eventually, the extent
of my illness really caught up with me.

526.62.text:
I was not in a position where I could keep
up appearances for anyone.

531.64.text:
After finding out the extent
of my exploits, one of my teachers told me

535.07.text:
that with my attitude,
I would never amount to anything.

537.70.text:
I dropped out of school
with no qualifications to my name.

541.10.text:
After three years
of frequent fits and seizures,

543.84.text:
I was eventually in a position
that I was able to stabilise.

546.97.text:
I spent a lot of evenings
then teaching myself

549.91.text: what I missed out on in school,

551.45.text:
and was able to secure a job
at the local cinema.

553.97.text: But after being there for a few years,

555.83.text:
I wanted to try and explore
employment avenues.

558.54.text:
It was difficult for someone
with no qualifications or experience

561.61.text: to break into the job market.

563.13.text:
Especially in an area
that I found meaningful.

565.70.text:
It was during this time that I came across
the Prince's Trust Programme.

569.10.text:
The Prince's Trust are a charity
that support young people,

575.40.text:
The Programme helped me immensely
with my self-confidence and self-esteem,

579.58.text:
beyond anything that I could
possibly comprehend.

581.95.text:
But most importantly, it helped me
to showcase my digital skills to employers

587.41.text:
Since my seizures have stopped,
I've worked on lots of projects.

591.71.text:
giving written and verbal
evidence in select committees,

596.43.text:
I worked on the digital designs
of an ITV documentary,

599.64.text:
and I worked with UK Space Agency
on a project for a Mars rover.

604.71.text:
I currently work for the Prince's Trust
on the Get Started Programme,

608.35.text: where I support other young people

609.99.text:
who are in a similar position
to the one I was in,

612.33.text: in the same way that I was supported.

615.68.text:
Among other factors,
having a high level of digital literacy

621.10.text:
gave me the opportunity
to overcome my disadvantage

623.72.text: and break into the job market.

625.27.text:
It's what we like to envision
technology doing;

628.39.text:
enabling a generation
using technology as an equaliser

631.56.text:
to get the opportunities
that they wouldn't have had otherwise.

634.53.text: But, having worked in the youth sector,

636.65.text:
I've gained a lot of exposure
to those who are adversely affected

643.53.text:
stems from the fact that our economic
system hasn't kept up

648.92.text:
In my opinion, I think
we've negated the human cost

651.53.text:
of aggressive digital expansion
in this country.

654.90.text:
Predominantly, because we are trying
to impart industrialised social values

658.43.text:
on a generation growing up,
in the digital era.

661.24.text:
The problem is, we don't know
what the future is going to look like.

664.44.text:
We can't predict the kind of jobs
that are going to be available.

667.50.text:
We don't know the kind of economy
that's going to shape our society.

670.73.text: But what we fundamentally do know,

672.47.text:
is part of the human experience
is that we are always

677.07.text:
Everyone in this room,
I'm sure at some point,

680.59.text: I'd be very surprised if you hadn't.

683.18.text:
What we need to know is
that these challenges require resilience

687.06.text: to be able to overcome them.

688.99.text: We know that the ability to solve problems

691.04.text:
is essential in developing
both coping mechanisms for mental health,

694.54.text:
and also for being able
to gain digital skills.

697.95.text:
We know young people are experiencing
higher levels of unemployment,

701.39.text: higher levels of mental health issues,

703.31.text:
increasing dissatisfaction
with their own well-being,

707.77.text:
and also, becoming more disengaged
as they try to get into the economy.

712.18.text:
The Equality and Human Rights Commission
published a paper this October

715.74.text:
that said that young people
have experienced

718.45.text:
the biggest slide in income
and employment,

721.02.text:
and face higher barriers
than five years ago.

723.99.text: In the 2015 Prince's Trust Youth Index,

726.86.text:
36% of young people said
they feel inadequate on a daily basis.

731.53.text:
That rose to over 53% of those who weren't
in employment, education, and training,

737.30.text:
and leaped again to 70% if that had been
the case for over six months.

741.68.text:
I think they're really shocking statistics
when you think about young people

745.38.text:
in this country,
at the moment; 70% of those

748.20.text:
not in employment, education,
or training, feeling inadequate.

752.85.text:
This year, young people scored the lowest
in the Index's seven year history,

759.77.text:
when it came to things like emotional
and physical well-being of themselves.

764.35.text:
We need to start looking
at how to drive a shift

766.63.text:
in principles and beliefs
for the digital revolution.

769.12.text: We need to prepare young people

770.81.text:
to take their place
in the digital economy.

772.95.text: And here's where I suggest we start:

774.71.text:
In a day and age where we have
a greater understanding of the human mind

779.05.text:
the most valuable asset that we can
pass on is coping mechanisms

782.06.text:
to be able to deal with challenges

785.44.text:
What is at the heart of
developing digital skills,

791.23.text:
What I want to see is more
compassion and understanding

795.38.text: Why can't we adopt the mindset

797.10.text:
that a high standard
of living is not the result

799.75.text:
of an individual's hard work
and intelligence,

801.92.text:
but that of a group,
a contribution of everyone?

805.69.text:
Because, ultimately,
we are all interconnected.

808.82.text: There is a brilliant African proverb:

813.97.text:
"If you want to go fast, go alone.
If you want to go far, go together."

818.59.text:
At the end of the day, without
somebody giving us a helping hand,

821.67.text: where would any of us be?

823.01.text: I definitely wouldn't be standing here

824.85.text:
if it wasn't for the compassion
and consideration of others.

827.65.text:
Personally, I don't think anyone
can say they made it alone.

830.60.text:
We are interdependent beings,
in an interdependent society,

833.70.text: and that needs to be reflected

835.21.text:
in the values we are imparting
to a generation.

838.15.text:
We must help everyone to not feel
isolated in a digital world.

the most valuable resource has been,
